needle: Figs are one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.
Prosciutto is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.
Goat cheese is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.

model_response.text:
It's 1990. I was about 25 years old, and I had just found out that I didn't
want to work on AI. I'd spent the previous 4 years at Cornell in the
computer science department, where I had learned Lisp and even started
writing the book that would become On Lisp, which was already a surprise
to me because I hadn't intended to write a book. As a result, I was
in a PhD program in computer science at Harvard, but I wasn't
working on it.[3] <PAUSE>  What was I doing, you might ask, at the age of 25?
I was trying to be an artist.[4] <PAUSE>  I was not alone.  Some people
at Harvard had the same idea that I did.  The year before, I'd
encountered a guy named Rich Draves who'd just finished his PhD
at Carnegie-Mellon and was now working in the computer science
department at Cornell.[5] <PAUSE>  He had a 2 year old son, and the
young man in the picture below looks just a few years younger than
Draves himself.I was in the painting studio, and he was working on his own
computer in the basement.  He showed me his program, and then
told me that he was taking a year off to write his first book, On Lisp.
That book, as I now see, was something I could have taken for a
book on computer science that I'd read when I was in high school, but
I had no intention of writing. And so in 1988, Draves and I
decided that the only way to get out of our grad schools was to
work together on his project.  I went back to Harvard for the 1989-90
academic year to help Draves (who had since become my friend, but we
weren't roommates) by working with him at Harvard and by building 
the first program based on his thesis idea, which was to build
a computer that could talk to other computers in its own language
(in order to facilitate a more efficient computer networking system).  It
was 5 years before the first networked computer would go live.  As I
say in On Lisp, the project was called the Pion and the first program
was called the Pion/SHR
